message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest albinism, which can be confirmed by neutral amino acid levels in urinalysis. Treatment includes sun protection and topical emollients. If needed, oral nitisinone can be used, which is associated with facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis is associated with excessive calcium excretion, irreversible retinopathy is associated with inherited retina-related illnesses, and calcium oxalate kidney stones are associated with hyperoxaluria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has tyrosinemia type II. Treatment includes administration of nitisinone, which is associated with facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis and calcium oxalate kidney stones are associated with Type I tyrosinemia, while irreversible retinopathy is associated with Wilson disease and other conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hyperpigmented rash on the patient’s face and extremities, along with the high levels of neutral amino acids in the urine, suggest a diagnosis of Hartnup disease. The appropriate treatment for Hartnup disease is nicotinamide, which can cause facial flushing as an adverse effect. The other options are associated with adverse effects of other medications used for different conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the rash, the urinary amino acid levels, and the clumsiness all suggest a diagnosis of Hartnup disease. Treatment for this condition involves administration of nicotinamide, which can be associated with facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis and calcium oxalate kidney stones are not associated with this condition or its treatment, and irreversible retinopathy is not a known adverse effect of nicotinamide.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The high levels of neutral amino acids and the rash on the face and extremities suggest a diagnosis of Hartnup disease. Treatment includes administration of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid, which are associated with facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis and calcium oxalate kidney stones are associated with other conditions, such as primary hyperparathyroidism and enteric hyperoxaluria, respectively. Irreversible retinopathy is not commonly associated with any of the available treatment options for Hartnup disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of cystinuria, a condition that causes cystine stones in the kidney and increased levels of neutral amino acids in the urine. Treatment includes administration of penicillamine, which is associated with facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis and calcium oxalate kidney stones are not associated with this condition, and irreversible retinopathy is not a known adverse effect of penicillamine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the most likely diagnosis is tyrosinemia type II, which is associated with the accumulation of tyrosine and its metabolites. Treatment includes administration of nitisinone, which can cause facial flushing as a common adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis and calcium oxalate kidney stones are associated with the use of vitamin D and/or calcium supplements, while irreversible retinopathy is a potential adverse effect of long-term use of hydroxychloroquine.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and high levels of neutral amino acids suggest a diagnosis of Hartnup disease, which can be treated with niacin. Facial flushing is a common adverse effect of niacin administration. None of the other options are associated with niacin administration.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest that the patient has tyrosinemia type II, which is treated with Nitisinone. Nitisinone is associated with facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis, irreversible retinopathy, and calcium oxalate kidney stones are not associated with Nitisinone.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described, including the pruritic rash and falls, suggest the patient has Hartnup disease, which can lead to niacin deficiency. Treatment includes niacin supplementation, which can cause facial flushing as an adverse effect. Nephrocalcinosis, irreversible retinopathy, and calcium oxalate kidney stones are not associated with niacin supplementation.
